items.name: Ext.util.Positionable
items.text: This mixin provides a common interface for objects that can be positioned, e.g. Ext.Component and Ext.dom.Element

items.name: getAnchorToXY
items.text:
Gets the x,y coordinates of an element specified by the anchor position on the
element.

items.name: el
items.text: The element

items.name: anchor
items.text: The specified anchor position. See alignTo for details on supported anchor positions.

items.name: local
items.text:
True to get the local (element top/left-relative) anchor
position instead of page coordinates

items.name: size
items.text:
An object containing the size to use for calculating anchor
position {width: (target width), height: (target height)} (defaults to the
element's current size)
[x, y] An array containing the element's x and y coordinates

items.name: getBorderPadding
items.text: Returns the size of the element's borders and padding.

an object with the following numeric properties
- beforeX
- afterX
- beforeY
- afterY

items.name: getLocalX
items.text: Returns the x coordinate of this element reletive to its `offsetParent`.
The local x coordinate

items.name: getLocalXY
items.text: Returns the x and y coordinates of this element relative to its `offsetParent`.
The local XY position of the element

items.name: getLocalY
items.text: Returns the y coordinate of this element reletive to its `offsetParent`.
The local y coordinate

items.name: getX
items.text: Gets the current X position of the DOM element based on page coordinates.
The X position of the element

items.name: getXY
items.text: Gets the current position of the DOM element based on page coordinates.
The XY position of the element

items.name: getY
items.text: Gets the current Y position of the DOM element based on page coordinates.
The Y position of the element

items.name: setLocalX
items.text: Sets the local x coordinate of this element using CSS style. When used on an absolute positioned element this method is symmetrical with getLocalX, but may not be symmetrical when used on a relatively positioned element.

items.name: x
items.text: The x coordinate. A value of null sets the left style to 'auto'.
this

items.name: setLocalXY
items.text: Sets the local x and y coordinates of this element using CSS style. When used on an absolute positioned element this method is symmetrical with getLocalXY, but may not be symmetrical when used on a relatively positioned element.

items.name: x
items.text: The x coordinate or an array containing [x, y]. A value of null sets the left style to 'auto'

items.name: y
items.text: The y coordinate, required if x is not an array. A value of null sets the top style to 'auto'
this

items.name: setLocalY
items.text: Sets the local y coordinate of this element using CSS style. When used on an absolute positioned element this method is symmetrical with getLocalY, but may not be symmetrical when used on a relatively positioned element.

items.name: y
items.text: The y coordinate. A value of null sets the top style to 'auto'.
this

items.name: setX
items.text: Sets the X position of the DOM element based on page coordinates.

items.name: x
items.text: The X position
this

items.name: setXY
items.text: Sets the position of the DOM element in page coordinates.

items.name: pos
items.text:
Contains X & Y [x, y] values for new position (coordinates
are page-based)
this

items.name: setY
items.text: Sets the Y position of the DOM element based on page coordinates.

items.name: y
items.text: The Y position
this

items.name: alignTo
items.text:
Aligns the element with another element relative to the specified anchor points. If the other element is the document it aligns it to the viewport. The position parameter is optional, and can be specified in any one of the following formats: - **Blank**: Defaults to aligning the element's top-left corner to the target's bottom-left corner ("tl-bl"). - **One anchor (deprecated)**: The passed anchor position is used as the target element's anchor point. The element being aligned will position its top-left corner (tl) to that point. *This method has been deprecated in favor of the newer two anchor syntax below*. - **Two anchors**: If two values from the table below are passed separated by a dash, the first value is used as the element's anchor point, and the second value is used as the target's anchor point. In addition to the anchor points, the position parameter also supports the "?" character. If "?" is passed at the end of the position string, the element will attempt to align as specified, but the position will be adjusted to constrain to the viewport if necessary. Note that the element being aligned might be swapped to align to a different position than that specified in order to enforce the viewport constraints. Following are all of the supported anchor positions: 
Value  Description
-----  -----------------------------
tl     The top left corner (default)
t      The center of the top edge
tr     The top right corner
l      The center of the left edge
c      In the center of the element
r      The center of the right edge
bl     The bottom left corner
b      The center of the bottom edge
br     The bottom right corner
Example Usage: // align el to other-el using the default positioning // ("tl-bl", non-constrained) el.alignTo("other-el"); // align the top left corner of el with the top right corner of other-el // (constrained to viewport) el.alignTo("other-el", "tr?"); // align the bottom right corner of el with the center left edge of other-el el.alignTo("other-el", "br-l?"); // align the center of el with the bottom left corner of other-el and // adjust the x position by -6 pixels (and the y position by 0) el.alignTo("other-el", "c-bl", [-6, 0]);

items.name: element
items.text:
The Positionable,
HTMLElement, or id of the element to align to.

items.name: position
items.text: The position to align to

items.name: offsets
items.text:
Offset the positioning by [x, y]
Element animation config object
this

items.name: calculateAnchorXY
items.text:
Calculates x,y coordinates specified by the anchor position on the element, adding
extraX and extraY values.

items.name: anchor
items.text: The specified anchor position. See alignTo for details on supported anchor positions.

items.name: extraX
items.text: value to be added to the x coordinate

items.name: extraY
items.text: value to be added to the y coordinate

items.name: size
items.text:
An object containing the size to use for calculating anchor
position {width: (target width), height: (target height)} (defaults to the
element's current size)
[x, y] An array containing the element's x and y coordinates

items.name: getAlignToXY
items.text: Gets the x,y coordinates to align this element with another element. See alignTo for more info on the supported position values.

items.name: element
items.text:
The Positionable,
HTMLElement, or id of the element to align to.

items.name: position
items.text: The position to align to

items.name: offsets
items.text: Offset the positioning by [x, y]
[x, y]

items.name: getAnchorXY
items.text: Gets the x,y coordinates specified by the anchor position on the element.

items.name: anchor
items.text: The specified anchor position. See alignTo for details on supported anchor positions.

items.name: local
items.text:
True to get the local (element top/left-relative) anchor
position instead of page coordinates

items.name: size
items.text:
An object containing the size to use for calculating anchor
position {width: (target width), height: (target height)} (defaults to the
element's current size)
[x, y] An array containing the element's x and y coordinates

items.name: getBox
items.text: Return an object defining the area of this Element which can be passed to setBox to set another Element's size/location to match this element.

items.name: contentBox
items.text:
If true a box for the content of the element is
returned.

items.name: local
items.text:
If true the element's left and top relative to its
`offsetParent` are returned instead of page x/y.
An object in the format

items.name: x
items.text: The element's X position.

items.name: y
items.text: The element's Y position.

items.name: width
items.text: The element's width.

items.name: height
items.text: The element's height.

items.name: bottom
items.text: The element's lower bound.

items.name: right
items.text: The element's rightmost bound. The returned object may also be addressed as an Array where index 0 contains the X position and index 1 contains the Y position. The result may also be used for setXY

items.name: calculateConstrainedPosition
items.text:
Calculates the new [x,y] position to move this Positionable into a constrain region.

By default, this Positionable is constrained to be within the container it was added to, or the element it was
rendered to.

Priority is given to constraining the top and left within the constraint.

An alternative constraint may be passed.

items.name: constrainTo
items.text: The Element or Ext.util.Region into which this Component is to be constrained. Defaults to the element into which this Positionable was rendered, or this Component's {@link Ext.Component#constrainTo.

items.name: proposedPosition
items.text:
A proposed `[X, Y]` position to test for validity
and to coerce into constraints instead of using this Positionable's current position.

items.name: local
items.text: The proposedPosition is local *(relative to floatParent if a floating Component)*

items.name: proposedSize
items.text:
A proposed `[width, height]` size to use when calculating
constraints instead of using this Positionable's current size.

**If** the element *needs* to be translated, the new `[X, Y]` position within
constraints if possible, giving priority to keeping the top and left edge in the constrain region.
Otherwise, `false`.

items.name: getConstrainRegion
items.text:
Returns the content region of this element for purposes of constraining floating
children.  That is the region within the borders and scrollbars, but not within the padding.

items.name: getConstrainVector
items.text: Returns the `[X, Y]` vector by which this Positionable's element must be translated to make a best attempt to constrain within the passed constraint. Returns `false` if the element does not need to be moved. Priority is given to constraining the top and left within the constraint. The constraint may either be an existing element into which the element is to be constrained, or a Ext.util.Region into which this element is to be constrained. By default, any extra shadow around the element is **not** included in the constrain calculations - the edges of the element are used as the element bounds. To constrain the shadow within the constrain region, set the `constrainShadow` property on this element to `true`.

items.name: constrainTo
items.text:
The
Positionable, HTMLElement, element id, or Region into which the element is to be
constrained.

items.name: proposedPosition
items.text:
A proposed `[X, Y]` position to test for validity
and to produce a vector for instead of using the element's current position

items.name: proposedSize
items.text:
A proposed `[width, height]` size to constrain
instead of using the element's current size

**If** the element *needs* to be translated, an `[X, Y]`
vector by which this element must be translated. Otherwise, `false`.

items.name: getOffsetsTo
items.text:
Returns the offsets of this element from the passed element. The element must both
be part of the DOM tree and not have display:none to have page coordinates.

items.name: offsetsTo
items.text:
The Positionable,
HTMLElement, or element id to get get the offsets from.
The XY page offsets (e.g. `[100, -200]`)

items.name: getRegion
items.text: Returns a region object that defines the area of this element.
A Region containing "top, left, bottom, right" properties.

items.name: getClientRegion
items.text:
Returns a region object that defines the client area of this element.

That is, the area *within* any scrollbars.
A Region containing "top, left, bottom, right" properties.

items.name: getViewRegion
items.text:
Returns the **content** region of this element. That is the region within the borders
and padding.
A Region containing "top, left, bottom, right" member data.

items.name: move
items.text: Move the element relative to its current position.

items.name: direction
items.text:
Possible values are:

- `"l"` (or `"left"`)
- `"r"` (or `"right"`)
- `"t"` (or `"top"`, or `"up"`)
- `"b"` (or `"bottom"`, or `"down"`)

items.name: distance
items.text: How far to move the element in pixels

items.name: setBox
items.text: Sets the element's box.

items.name: box
items.text: The box to fill {x, y, width, height}
this

items.name: translatePoints
items.text: Translates the passed page coordinates into left/top css values for the element

items.name: x
items.text: The page x or an array containing [x, y]

items.name: y
items.text: The page y, required if x is not an array

An object with left and top properties. e.g.
{left: (value), top: (value)}

items.name: translateXY
items.text: Translates the passed page coordinates into x and y css values for the element

items.name: x
items.text: The page x or an array containing [x, y]

items.name: y
items.text: The page y, required if x is not an array

An object with x and y properties. e.g.
{x: (value), y: (value)}

items.name: reverseTranslateXY
items.text: Converts local coordinates into page-level coordinates

items.name: xy
items.text: The local x and y coordinates
The translated coordinates

items.name: convertPositionSpec
items.text:
By default this method does nothing but return the position spec passed to it. In
rtl mode it is overridden to convert "l" to "r" and vice versa when required.
